docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students explore how humor can be used to teach important lessons, create storyboards for a cartoon that teaches younger children about the importance of hand washing, and critique a popular cartoon.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students explore how humor can be used to teach important lessons, create storyboards for a cartoon that teaches younger children about the importance of hand washing, and critique a popular cartoon.

byline.original: By SARAH KAVANAGH and BRIDGET ANDERSON

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration made a reasonable call that will allow women, in consultation with their surgeons, to make their own judgments about silicone breast implants.

docs.lead_paragraph: The subjects in “Living Old” who come across most vividly are the ones who don’t talk about aging or death. Instead they talk about their lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. lifted a 14-year ban on the use of silicone gel breast implants in the U.S. following many years of debate over their safety.

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug already shown to reverse the effects of obesity in mice and make them live longer has now been shown to increase their endurance as well.

docs.lead_paragraph: The death rate from falling has risen about 55 percent for people 65 and older in the United States since the 1990s, federal health officials said.
